title-group.article-title: Effect of atmospheres on tribological property of plasma-sprayed NiCr–Ag composite coating

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Laboratory of Solid Lubrication, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Science, People’s Republic of China

abstract.p: NiCr–Ag composite solid lubricant coating was deposited on stainless steel by atmospheric plasma spray. The microhardness, phase composition and microstructure of as-sprayed coating were characterized. Meanwhile, the friction and wear behaviour of as-sprayed coating sliding against ceramic (Si3N4) ball in air, argon and oxygen were evaluated using a ball-on-disc friction and wear test rig. It was found that when sliding against Si3N4 in oxygen, the composite coating underwent severe oxidative wear and splat delamination, showing the highest friction coefficient and wear rate. When sliding against Si3N4 in argon, the composite coating had the lowest friction coefficient and wear rate; and in this case, no crack and splat delamination could be observed on the worn surface because of the elimination of oxidation of the coating and enrichment of solid lubricant silver on sliding surface in inert atmosphere. In addition, the friction coefficients of the as-sprayed coating in all three atmospheres decreased with the increase of sliding speed or load.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Solid lubricant coatings are primarily adopted to reduce the friction and wear of various frictional pairs under extreme conditions of load, speed and reversed thermal cycling environments, where conventional lubricants usually cannot provide favourable performance.1,2 Various methods such as powder metallurgy,3,4 laser cladding5,6 and thermal spray7,8 can be utilized to prepare self-lubricating coatings. Thanks to the extremely wide variety of materials that can be used to produce coatings and the ability to apply coatings to substrates without significant heat input, thermal spray process is of particular significance in coating technology. Besides, thermal spray method can be used to recoat worn or damaged coatings without changing substrate properties and dimensions.9 This is why thermal spray technology is so popular in preparing self-lubricating coatings.

In terms of the application of various self-lubricating coatings, Ni-based solid lubricant is of particular interest in sealed systems, gas turbine parts and nuclear systems,10,11 due to its excellent self-lubricating properties over a wide range of temperature. It has been well recognized that silver (Ag) has a larger diffusion coefficient and low shearing stress, which makes it an extremely attractive lubricant for many mechanical components such as bearings, seals and fasteners, due to its good lubricity over a wide range of temperatures.12,13 Therefore, Ni-based self-lubricating composites doped with Ag possess excellent lubricity due to the combination of the advantages of the two components. Driven by this prospect, NASA has successfully developed a series of Ag-doped Ni-based self-lubricating coatings with a working temperature from room temperature to 800°C by plasma spray, where Ag acts as a thermochemically stable solid lubricant at relatively lower temperature from room temperature to approximately 450°C.14,15 Tyagi et al.16 investigated the friction and wear behaviour of Ni-based composites containing a combination of solid lubricants Ag and h-BN, and they found that the introduction of the combinatory solid lubricants reduced the friction coefficient from 0.36 to 0.21. Nevertheless, few studies are reported about the friction and wear behaviour of Ag-containing Ni-based composites in different atmospheres. The friction and wear behaviour of tribo-pairs under the participation of atmosphere are quite distinct from those of air condition.17,18 Shafiei and Alpas19 investigated the friction and wear mechanisms of nanocrystalline Ni in ambient and argon (Ar) atmospheres, and found that nanocrystalline Ni showed higher wear rate and friction coefficient in Ar. DellaCorte and Sliney20 studied the effects of atmosphere on the tribological properties of a plasma-sprayed chromium carbide-based self-lubricating coating, and discovered that specimens tested in hydrogen, a reducing environment, exhibited the best tribological properties.

Bearing that perspective in mind and noticing that more and more tribo-pairs need to work under extreme atmospheres in industry,21,22 we focus on the comparison of the friction and wear behaviour as well as wear mechanism of Ni-based self-lubricating coating in air, Ar and oxygen (O2) in this research. Thus, NiCr–Ag composite coating was prepared by atmospheric plasma spray. The friction and wear behaviours of as-sprayed NiCr–Ag composite coating in air, Ar and O2 were comparatively evaluated, and the wear mechanisms of the coating in different environments discussed.

sec.title: Preparation of NiCr–Ag composite coating
sec.p:
Commercially obtained feedstock powders of NiCr (Ni-20Cr) and Ag were provided by Beijing Research Institute of Mining & Metallurgy (Beijing, China). Before spraying was done, they were blended at a mass fraction of 90:10. Both NiCr and Ag particles are spherical, and they have sizes of ranges 50∼100 and 80∼120 µm, respectively (Figure 1(a) and (b)). Figure 1.
SEM morphologies of feedstock powders of (a) NiCr and (b) Ag.

Stainless steel (1Cr18Ni9Ti) discs (24 mm in diameter, 7.75 mm in thickness) with composition oFe-0.1C-1.0Si-2.0Mn-18Cr-9Ni (wt%) were used as the substrates. Prior to plasma spraying, the substrates were sand blasted with corundum grits. An APS2000 atmospheric plasma spray system equipped with a PQ-1S plasma gun (Institute of Aeronautical Manufacturing Technology, Beijing, China) was used to deposit NiCr–Ag composite coating on the sand-blasted substrate under spraying parameters (Ar flow rate 40 L/min, voltage 550 V, current 60 A, powder feed rate 45 g/min and spraying distance 100 mm).

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: The morphologies of the feedstock powders and as-sprayed NiCr–Ag composite coating were observed using a JSM-5600LV scanning electron microscope (JEOL Corporation, Japan) equipped with an energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) and a backscattered electron (BSE) detector. The phase compositions of the feedstocks and composite coatings were characterized by a Philips X’Pert MPD X-ray diffractometer (XRD; Netherlands; Cu-Kα radiation) over an angular range from 30° to 90°. The microhardness of the composite coating was evaluated by MH-5VM microhardness tester at a load of 200 g for a duration of 10 s. The porosity of the coating was measured by OLYCIAm3 image analysis software. The worn surfaces of the tribo-pairs and wear debris were analysed using the SEM and a Micro XAM three-dimensional (3D) non-contact surface mapping profiler (ADE Corporation, Massachusetts, USA). The elemental composition of the wear debris was determined using the EDS.

A ball-on-disc tribometer (CSM, Tribo-S-D-0000) equipped with an environment chamber where the gaseous environment could be controlled was adopted to evaluate the friction and wear behaviour of the NiCr–Ag composite coating sliding against commercially obtained Si3N4 balls (Ø6 mm, 1700HV2N) in air, Ar and O2 atmospheres. Before the test, the plasma-sprayed coating was mechanically grounded with 1200 grit emery paper and ultrasonically cleaned in acetone for 5 min. The relative humidity of air was kept in the range 20–30%. The purity of Ar and O2 gases used was better than 99.99% and their relative humidity less than 10%. The sliding wear tests were conducted at room temperature at three different loads 2, 5 and 8 N with a constant speed of 20 cm/s corresponding to contact pressures of 509.1, 690.9 and 808.1 MPa, respectively, and three different sliding speeds 10, 20 and 30 cm/s with a constant load of 5 N. The ambient temperature was 20°C and the sliding distance 360 m. Three replicated tests were conducted for each wear test condition and the averaged value was given. The friction coefficient curves were automatically recorded with a computer, and the wear rate was calculated as W = V/SF, where V is the wear volume loss in mm3, S the total sliding distance in m and F the applied load in N.

sec.title: Characterization of feedstock powders and NiCr–Ag composite coating
sec.p:
Figure 1 gives the SEM morphologies of NiCr and Ag feedstock powders. It can be seen that both NiCr and Ag powders are spherical, which is beneficial to the powders’ flow ability, since the quality of thermally sprayed coating is highly dependent on the flow properties of the feedstock powders.23,24 The apparent density and flowability of the powders are listed in Table 1. Both NiCr and Ag powders show excellent flowability and similar apparent density, which means that NiCr and Ag powders to-be-sprayed have similar flight behaviour during spray process. Table 1.
Flowability and density of sprayed NiCr and Ag powders.
Powders Flow time (s/50 g) Apparent density (g/cm3) Tap density (g/cm3)
NiCr 16.53 4.47 5.02
Ag 10.41 6.21 6.62
Blended powders 14.02 4.71 5.25

Figure 2 presents the XRD patterns of NiCr–Ag feedstock and as-sprayed NiCr–Ag composite coating. It can be identified from Figure 2 that plasma-sprayed NiCr–Ag composite coating consists of NiCr and Ag phases. No other new phases are detected in as-sprayed NiCr–Ag composite coating, which indicates that the feedstock powders are deposited on the substrate without experiencing any obvious oxidation or decomposition. Besides, the XRD peaks of NiCr–Ag composite coating are broadened, which is highly dependent on the thermal spray process. Namely, when the feedstock powder was melted by the heat source and ejected onto the cooler substrate during thermal spray process, the rapid cooling of the molten particles results in non-equilibrium and metastable phases in the coating.25 Figure 2.
XRD patterns of (a) NiCr–Ag feedstock powders and (b) NiCr–Ag composite coating.

Figure 3 shows the cross-sectional SEM and BSE images of as-sprayed NiCr–Ag composite coating. It can be seen that as-sprayed NiCr–Ag composite coating has a compact structure and contains a small amount of unmelted particles. EDS analysis shows that the bright areas in Figure 3(b) are Ag, the grey areas NiCr and the black areas pores. In the meantime, NiCr phase is tightly bonded with Ag phase in the composite coating, and no evident cracks exist at the interface of the two phases. Image analysis shows that NiCr–Ag composite coating has a porosity of 2.5%, and its microhardness is 220 Vickers. Figure 3.
Polished cross-sectional SEM morphologies of NiCr–Ag composite coating: (a) SEM and (b) BSE images.

sec.title: Friction and wear behaviour
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows typical friction coefficient curves of NiCr–Ag composite coating sliding against its Si3N4 counterpart as functions of sliding distance in air, Ar and O2 at an applied load of 5 N and a speed of 20 cm/s. It can be seen that NiCr–Ag coating sliding against Si3N4 in O2 has the highest average friction coefficient of about 0.9; and it has the lowest friction coefficient when sliding against the same ceramic counterpart in Ar. Besides, the friction coefficient in O2 tends to obviously increase from 0.6 to 1.0 within the early stage of sliding (up to 40 m), and the average friction coefficient in air lies in between (about 0.5) and also shows a large fluctuation. Two competing factors may be responsible for the larger fluctuation of friction coefficient in air. On one hand, the wear debris produced during friction test may get locked between the sliding surfaces and promote three-body wear. On the other hand, the debris can be compacted to form a protective layer to reduce friction and wear.16 Moreover, it seems that the friction coefficients in both air and Ar tend to slowly increase with extending sliding distance. In particular, no evident wear debris was produced when the composite coating slid against the ceramic ball in Ar, whereas a large amount of black wear debris was found when it slid against the same counterpart in air and O2 atmospheres, corresponding well to relevant changing tendency of the friction coefficient. Figure 4.
Variation of friction coefficient of NiCr–Ag composite coating in different atmospheres with sliding distance at 5 N and 20 cm/s.

Figures 5 and 6 show the variation of friction coefficients of composite coating with applied loads at a constant sliding speed of 20 cm/s and with sliding speeds at a constant load of 5 N in air, Ar and O2. It can be seen from Figure 5 that coefficients decrease with increased loads in all three atmospheres. Meanwhile, as observed in Figure 6, friction coefficients of composite coating also show a continuously decreasing trend with increased speed. Figure 5.
Variation of average friction coefficient with load at a constant speed of 20 cm/s. Figure 6.
Variation of average friction coefficient with sliding speed at a constant load of 5 N.

Figures 7 and 8 present the variation of the wear rates of composite coating with applied loads at a constant speed of 20 cm/s and with sliding speeds at a constant load of 5 N. The wear rates in Ar are significantly smaller than those in air and O2 at all test conditions. It can be found from Figure 7 that the wear rates are increased with increase in applied loads. In Figure 8, we can also find that with the increase of sliding speed, the wear rates show an initial decrease, and then increase beyond a speed of 20 cm/s. Compared to 10 and 30 cm/s, the values of wear rate in all three atmospheres are smallest at 20 cm/s. It can be inferred that the formation of compacted transfer layer is a more prominent factor in reducing the wear rate of the coating at 20 cm/s. Figure 7.
Variation of wear rate with load at a constant speed of 20 cm/s. Figure 8.
Variation of wear rate with sliding speed at a constant load of 5 N.

The effects of load and speed on the friction and wear properties of NiCr–Ag composite coating can be further confirmed by Figures 9 and 10. Figure 9 exhibits the SEM morphologies of the worn surfaces of composite coating in three atmospheres at varied loads and a constant speed of 20 cm/s. In Figure 9, it is seen that the worn surface in all three atmospheres is smoother at 8 N than that at 2 N. This may be so because as load increases, the frictional heat is effective in forming compacted wear debris and larger coverage of transfer layer. In Figure 10, it can also be observed that the worn surfaces in three atmospheres become smoother as the sliding speed increases from 10 to 30 cm/s. More frictional heat is produced at higher sliding speed, which is helpful in forming a compacted transfer layer. The wear rate of the NiCr–Ag coating has been generally observed to increase with the increasing load. This phenomenon can be explained by the coating suffering higher Hertz load and repeated shear stress with increased load, which leads to higher wear rate, though high load can help in forming compacted wear debris. Figure 9.
SEM micrographs of worn surfaces of NiCr–Ag composite coating: (a) air, 2 N 20 cm/s; (b) air, 8 N 20 cm/s; (c) Ar, 2 N 20 cm/s; (d) Ar, 8 N 20 cm/s; (e) O2, 2 N 20 cm/s; and (f) O2, 8 N 20 cm/s. Figure 10.
SEM micrographs of worn surfaces of NiCr–Ag composite coating: (a) air, 5 N 10 cm/s; (b) air, 5 N 30 cm/s; (c) Ar, 5 N 10 cm/s; (d) Ar, 5 N 30 cm/s; (e) O2, 5 N 10 cm/s; and (f) O2, 5 N 30 cm/s.

Figure 11 shows the micrographs of the worn surfaces of NiCr–Ag composite coating tested in air, Ar and O2 at 5 N and 20 cm/s. As seen in Figure 5(a), the worn surface of NiCr–Ag composite coating sliding against Si3N4 in air is dominated by parallel scratches, which are attributed to abrasive wear by the Si3N4 counterpart with a much higher hardness than the as-sprayed composite coating; some pits are found on the worn surface due to splat delamination of the thermally sprayed composite coating with weak intersplat cohesion. Besides, a smooth glaze layer is observed in the worn surface of the composite coating in air, which is attributed to the compaction of wear debris. The worn surface of the composite coating sliding against Si3N4 in O2 is dominated by pits and scratches (Figure 11(c)), which is closely related to the accelerated oxidation of the coating at elevated temperatures in the presence of O2. The oxidized products are liable to form wear debris under sustained shear force during sliding. The wear debris composed of oxidized products of the friction pair is finally compacted and deposited on wear track, leading to severe three-body abrasive wear and hence significantly increased friction coefficient and wear rate. Contrary to the above, no cavities are visible on the wear track of the NiCr–Ag composite coating sliding against Si3N4 in Ar, and only a few shallow grooves emerge thereon. This may be dependent on two factors. On the one hand, as-sprayed coating has no chance to be oxidized when it slides against Si3N4 in inert Ar, thus greatly reducing the possibility of splat delamination. On the other hand, in the absence of splat delamination, Ag with excellent lubricity in as-sprayed composite coating can enrich on the sliding surface to form a lubricating film and result in reduced friction coefficient and wear rate, which is supported by the elemental composition of the wear tracks of the as-sprayed NiCr–Ag composite coating sliding against Si3N4 in different atmospheres (Table 2). Indeed, the worn surface of the composite coating in Ar consists of the largest amount of Ag and the smallest amount of Si. Figure 11.
SEM micrographs of worn surfaces of NiCr–Ag composite coating at 5 N and 20 cm/s: (a) air, (b) Ar and (c) O2. Table 2.
EDS analysis of the worn surface of NiCr–Ag coating at 5 N and 20 cm/s in air, Ar and O2.

Ni Cr Ag Si
Air 68.05 15.97 13.47 2.51
Ar 49.92 12.46 35.84 1.78
O2 67.72 16.36 12.98 2.94

Figure 12 shows the 3D non-contact surface mapping of the wear scars of NiCr–Ag composite coating in air, Ar and O2 at 5 N and 20 cm/s. It can be seen that the wear scar in O2 is the widest and deepest, that in air lies in between, and the one in Ar is the narrowest and shallowest, corresponding well to relevant SEM images of worn surfaces and wear rate of the composite coating in different atmospheres. Besides, two peaks appear on the edges of the wear scar of the as-sprayed composite coating in Ar, corresponding to its plastic deformation under Hertz load. Figure 12.
Three-dimensional non-contact surface mapping of the worn surface of NiCr–Ag coating at 5 N and 20 cm/s: (a) air, (b) Ar and (c) O2.

Figure 13 shows the SEM images of the worn surfaces of counterpart Si3N4 balls sliding against NiCr–Ag composite coating at 5 N and 20 cm/s in air, Ar and O2. It is seen that the worn surfaces of the Si3N4 balls in air and O2 show grooves and adhesion pits, whereas the worn ceramic ball surface in Ar is relatively smooth and shows only hint sign of scratching and adhesion. This indicates that the counterpart ceramic balls suffer more severe wear in air and O2 than in Ar. When friction and wear tests were conducted in air and O2, flake-like wear debris were generated and compacted on sliding surface under repeated shear and compressive stresses, forming detached wear debris consisting of hard particles that originated from the coating and Si3N4 ball and resulting in severe three-body abrasive wear. When friction and wear tests were conducted in inert Ar, however, oxidative wear was eliminated and splat detachment of the coating considerably prevented. As a result, Si3N4 ball experienced no three-body abrasive wear and hence the scratching and adhesion on its worn surface were greatly weakened. Besides, solid lubricant Ag with poor wettability to Si3N4 ball in Ar might also contribute to the significantly retarded adhesion on the worn surface of the ceramic ball, due to lack of transfer film thereon.26 Figure 13.
SEM images of worn surfaces of Si3N4 ball against NiCr–Ag coating at 5 N and 20 cm/s: (a) air, (b) Ar and (c) O2.

Figure 14 shows the SEM images of the wear debris of NiCr–Ag coating at 5 N and 20 cm/s in air and O2. When sliding against Si3N4 in Ar, as-sprayed NiCr–Ag composite coating was dominated by plastic deformation and free of splat delamination. As a result, no evident wear debris was found at the end of the friction and wear test in Ar. Lamella-like wear debris were collected at the end of the friction and wear tests in both air and O2 atmospheres. However, the size of the wear debris in O2 is about four times that in air, corresponding to more serious splat delamination of the as-sprayed coating in O2. The elemental compositions of the wear debris in air and O2, analysed by EDS, are listed in Table 3. It can be seen that the wear debris in O2 consists of a larger amount of Si and Ag. This indicates that the counterpart Si3N4 ball suffers more severe abrasion and damage in O2, since Si element in the wear debris is originated from the ceramic ball. Besides, a larger amount of Ag in the wear debris in O2 corresponds to severe detachment and loss of solid lubricant Ag in the composite coating, conforming to poorer wear resistance of the coating in O2. sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Self-lubricating NiCr–Ag composite coating was produced on stainless steel by atmospheric plasma spray. NiCr–Ag coating in Ar shows the lowest friction coefficient and wear rate compared with that in air and O2, which is attributed to the enrichment of Ag on the sliding surface and the alleviation of splat flaking. When sliding against Si3N4 in O2, NiCr–Ag coating has the highest friction coefficient and wear rate, which is attributed to the accelerated oxidation of the coating. The friction coefficients in all atmospheres decrease with increasing speed and load due to the presence of smooth transfer layer at high speed and load. We may come to the conclusion that atmospheric plasma-sprayed NiCr–Ag self-lubricating composite coating exhibits poor lubricating property in oxidizing atmosphere and shows excellent lubrication function in O2-free atmosphere.
